    <item>
      <guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.nbcnews.com/storyline/zika-virus-outbreak/zika-s-approach-u-s-raises-tricky-abortion-questions-n572751</guid>
      <title>Zika's U.S. Approach Raises Abortion Question</title>
      <pubDate>Thu, 12 May 2016 13:32:30 GMT</pubDate>
      <link>http://www.nbcnews.com/storyline/zika-virus-outbreak/zika-s-approach-u-s-raises-tricky-abortion-questions-n572751</link>
      <dc:creator />
      <description>Zika's definitely coming to the U.S., bringing with it catastrophic birth defects. What will that do to the abortion debate?</description>
      <media:content url="http://media1.s-nbcnews.com/i/newscms/2016_12/1468866/160322-health-zika-puerto-rico_fddcd7ea883b4c54c9cf16fd75ba057b.jpg" medium="image" height="2335" width="3500">
        <media:credit>ALVIN BAEZ</media:credit>
        <media:text type="plain">Image: Nancy Trinidad, who is 32 weeks pregnant, listens to the explanation of a doctor about how to prevent Zika, Dengue and Chikungunya viruses at a public hospital in San Juan</media:text>
        <media:description type="plain">Nancy Trinidad, who is 32 weeks pregnant, listens to the explanation of a doctor about how to prevent Zika, Dengue and Chikungunya viruses at a public hospital in San Juan, Puerto Rico, February 3, 2016. REUTERS/Alvin Baez</media:description>
      </media:content>
      <media:content url="http://media3.s-nbcnews.com/i/newscms/2016_13/1478526/160330-mri-zika-baby-yh-0447p_dcad28d67965c7d07e2e4a000ba31c59.jpg" medium="image" height="1421" width="2500">
        <media:credit>Courtesy of Johns Hopkins Sibley Memorial Hospital</media:credit>
        <media:text type="plain">Image: Zika effects on fetus</media:text>
        <media:description type="plain">This MRI picture (19-week) of the baby with zika on the left shows that the brain of the fetus with Zika is only 1.4mm thick compared to a healthy fetus on the right, which is 8mm thick.</media:description>
      </media:content>
    </item>
    <item>
      <guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.nbcnews.com/nightly-news/video/strokes-on-the-rise-among-younger-adults-study-finds-684819523846</guid>
      <title>Strokes On the Rise Among Younger Adults: Study</title>
      <pubDate>Fri, 13 May 2016 06:50:55 GMT</pubDate>
      <link>http://www.nbcnews.com/nightly-news/video/strokes-on-the-rise-among-younger-adults-study-finds-684819523846</link>
      <dc:creator />
      <description>A new study has found that over 10 years, there has been a 44 percent increase in strokes for people aged 25 to 44 years old.</description>
    </item>
    <item>
      <guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.nbcnews.com/storyline/zika-virus-outbreak/senate-strikes-1-1-billion-bipartisan-deal-pay-zika-fight-n573266</guid>
      <title>Senate Strikes $1.1 Billion Deal to Pay for Zika Fight</title>
      <pubDate>Fri, 13 May 2016 00:06:00 GMT</pubDate>
      <link>http://www.nbcnews.com/storyline/zika-virus-outbreak/senate-strikes-1-1-billion-bipartisan-deal-pay-zika-fight-n573266</link>
      <dc:creator>Maggie Fox</dc:creator>
      <description>The Senate has a bipartisan compromise deal to give President Obama more than half the money he's asked for to fight the Zika virus.</description>
      <media:content url="http://media1.s-nbcnews.com/i/newscms/2016_11/1460891/160316-zika-cuba-fumigation-truck_eb6147d42fcbd04ded8ffb3939816bc6.jpg" medium="image" height="2349" width="3500">
        <media:credit>ENRIQUE DE LA OSA</media:credit>
        <media:text type="plain">Image: A military truck carries out fumigation in a neighborhood to stop the breeding of the dengue mosquito in Havana</media:text>
        <media:description type="plain">A military truck carries out fumigation in a neighborhood to stop the breeding of the dengue mosquito in Havana March 1, 2016. </media:description>
      </media:content>
      <media:content url="http://media3.s-nbcnews.com/i/newscms/2016_12/1469896/160323-160127-health-zika-puerto-rico_bcafc4a72f3144474d8733c3337f0ed6.jpg" medium="image" height="2334" width="3500">
        <media:credit>ALVIN BAEZ</media:credit>
        <media:text type="plain">Image: A health worker prepares insecticide before fumigating in a neighborhood in San Juan.</media:text>
        <media:description type="plain">A health worker prepares insecticide before fumigating in a neighborhood in San Juan, January 27, 2016.  </media:description>
      </media:content>
    </item>
    <item>
      <guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/judge-rules-us-house-obamacare-challenge-n573086</guid>
      <title>Judge Rules for House GOP in Challenge to Obamacare</title>
      <pubDate>Thu, 12 May 2016 17:29:00 GMT</pubDate>
      <link>http://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/judge-rules-us-house-obamacare-challenge-n573086</link>
      <dc:creator>Pete Williams</dc:creator>
      <description>A federal judge in Washington ruled for House Republicans Thursday in the latest challenge to the Obama health care law.</description>
      <media:content url="http://media4.s-nbcnews.com/i/newscms/2016_08/1392111/160127-obamacare111-1029_f314eb93df69ce7d53100a290f013614.jpg" medium="image" height="1667" width="2500">
        <media:credit>© Jonathan Bachman / Reuters</media:credit>
        <media:text type="plain">Image: From the Files: State of the Union</media:text>
        <media:description type="plain">The federal government forms for applying for health coverage are seen at a rally held by supporters of the Affordable Care Act.</media:description>
      </media:content>
      <media:content url="http://media4.s-nbcnews.com/i/newscms/2016_08/1392111/160127-obamacare111-1029_f314eb93df69ce7d53100a290f013614.jpg" medium="image" height="1667" width="2500">
        <media:credit>© Jonathan Bachman / Reuters</media:credit>
        <media:text type="plain">Image: From the Files: State of the Union</media:text>
        <media:description type="plain">The federal government forms for applying for health coverage are seen at a rally held by supporters of the Affordable Care Act.</media:description>
      </media:content>
    </item>
    <item>
      <guid isPermaLink="false">http://time.com/4326721/air-pollution-poor-cities/</guid>
      <title>80 Percent of Urban Dwellers Live With Unsafe Air Pollution</title>
      <pubDate>Thu, 12 May 2016 07:57:33 GMT</pubDate>
      <link>http://time.com/4326721/air-pollution-poor-cities/</link>
      <dc:creator />
      <description>A World Health Organization report suggests that global urban pollution levels increased by 8 percent in the five years preceding 2013.</description>
      <media:content url="http://media4.s-nbcnews.com/i/newscms/2016_19/1533926/160512-air-pollution-0350_6d6dc541bbc02fecebc13a8e05dfeec1.jpg" medium="image" height="2344" width="4160">
        <media:credit>Frank Augstein</media:credit>
        <media:text type="plain">Image: Anti-pollution protest in London on April 27, 2016</media:text>
        <media:description type="plain">An anti-pollution protest in London, England, on April 27, 2016.</media:description>
      </media:content>
    </item>
    <item>
      <guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/fda-redefine-what-healthy-really-means-n572426</guid>
      <title>FDA to Redefine What 'Healthy' Food Really Means</title>
      <pubDate>Wed, 11 May 2016 22:39:00 GMT</pubDate>
      <link>http://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/fda-redefine-what-healthy-really-means-n572426</link>
      <dc:creator>Tom Costello</dc:creator>
      <description>How is it possible a sugary cereal could be considered healthy but not almonds, avocados and salmon? The FDA is wants to redefine "healthy" food.</description>
      <media:content url="http://media3.s-nbcnews.com/i/newscms/2015_02/838546/today-avocado-150107-01_78a9d127f713343603467e75463b5fba.jpg" medium="image" height="1407" width="2500">
        <media:credit>AP</media:credit>
        <media:text type="plain">Image:</media:text>
        <media:description type="plain">This Dec. 15, 2014 photo shows avocados in Concord, N.H. (AP Photo/Matthew Mead)</media:description>
      </media:content>
    </item>
    <item>
      <guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.nbcnews.com/health/aging/new-imaging-technique-may-find-real-alzheimer-s-culprit-n572416</guid>
      <title>New Scan Looks for Real Alzheimer's Culprit</title>
      <pubDate>Wed, 11 May 2016 20:52:00 GMT</pubDate>
      <link>http://www.nbcnews.com/health/aging/new-imaging-technique-may-find-real-alzheimer-s-culprit-n572416</link>
      <dc:creator>Lauran Neergaard, Associated Press</dc:creator>
      <description>PET scans that highlight the tangle-causing protein tau may better predict memory loss of Alzheimer's than older methods, researchers say.</description>
      <media:content url="http://media2.s-nbcnews.com/i/newscms/2016_19/1533456/460x_94a8e046397cb90fdaad356ae3ea6e0a.jpg" medium="image" height="294" width="460">
        <media:credit>(Robert Boston/Washington University via AP)</media:credit>
        <media:text type="plain"></media:text>
        <media:description type="plain">Associate professor of neurology at Washington University School of Medicine Beau Ances MD, PhD, right, and Matthew Brier an MD/PhD student at the university, examining PET (positron emission tomography) scans of Alzheimer's disease patients, in St. Louis. Scientists are peeking inside living brains to watch for the first time as a toxic duo of plaques and tangles interact to drive Alzheimer's disease, with implications for better treatments. (Robert Boston/Washington University via AP)</media:description>
      </media:content>
      <media:content url="http://media3.s-nbcnews.com/i/newscms/2016_19/1533466/115284_0271f14985d4d5081fe21fe6777ea544.jpg" medium="image" height="800" width="1200">
        <media:credit>Matthew R. Brier</media:credit>
        <media:text type="plain"></media:text>
        <media:description type="plain">A study using a new PET imaging agent shows that measures of tau protein in the brain more closely track cognitive decline due to Alzheimer's disease</media:description>
      </media:content>
    </item>
    <item>
      <guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.nbcnews.com/health/health-care/americans-oppose-fast-approvals-want-drug-ads-tv-survey-n572301</guid>
      <title>Most Americans Oppose Drug Ads on TV</title>
      <pubDate>Wed, 11 May 2016 19:07:00 GMT</pubDate>
      <link>http://www.nbcnews.com/health/health-care/americans-oppose-fast-approvals-want-drug-ads-tv-survey-n572301</link>
      <dc:creator>Dan Mangan, CNBC</dc:creator>
      <description>Those 'ask your doctor about ...' drug ads on TV? Americans are asking not to see any more of them. They also don't want rushed FDA drug approvals.</description>
      <media:content url="http://media1.s-nbcnews.com/i/newscms/2015_37/1216356/150910-fda-hq-building-yh-0223p_b384e76c46c767939064b815b5b5cd19.jpg" medium="image" height="2057" width="2500">
        <media:credit>Jason Reed  </media:credit>
        <media:text type="plain">Image: The headquarters of the U.S. Food and Drug Administration  </media:text>
        <media:description type="plain">FDA.</media:description>
      </media:content>
    </item>
    <item>
      <guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.nbcnews.com/storyline/zika-virus-outbreak/brazilian-researchers-find-evidence-zika-getting-worse-n572186</guid>
      <title>Researchers Find Evidence Zika Is Getting Even Worse</title>
      <pubDate>Wed, 11 May 2016 17:00:00 GMT</pubDate>
      <link>http://www.nbcnews.com/storyline/zika-virus-outbreak/brazilian-researchers-find-evidence-zika-getting-worse-n572186</link>
      <dc:creator>Maggie Fox</dc:creator>
      <description>Brazilian researchers studying Zika virus say they've found evidence it may have evolved into a new form that's more likely to cause birth defects.</description>
      <media:content url="http://media2.s-nbcnews.com/i/newscms/2016_19/1533156/zika-electro_f8ad0b5efa522713354bc8a4b86437f6.jpg" medium="image" height="480" width="512">
        <media:credit>Richard Kuhn, Purdue University</media:credit>
        <media:text type="plain"></media:text>
        <media:description type="plain">A cryo-electron microscopy image of the Zika virus structure. The triangle highlights the asymmetric unit of the virus.</media:description>
      </media:content>
      <media:content url="http://media2.s-nbcnews.com/i/newscms/2016_19/1533156/zika-electro_f8ad0b5efa522713354bc8a4b86437f6.jpg" medium="image" height="480" width="512">
        <media:credit>Richard Kuhn, Purdue University</media:credit>
        <media:text type="plain"></media:text>
        <media:description type="plain">A cryo-electron microscopy image of the Zika virus structure. The triangle highlights the asymmetric unit of the virus.</media:description>
      </media:content>
    </item>
    <item>
      <guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.nbcnews.com/storyline/zika-virus-outbreak/here-s-what-zika-virus-infection-looks-n572106</guid>
      <title>Here's What Zika Virus Infection Looks Like</title>
      <pubDate>Wed, 11 May 2016 15:01:00 GMT</pubDate>
      <link>http://www.nbcnews.com/storyline/zika-virus-outbreak/here-s-what-zika-virus-infection-looks-n572106</link>
      <dc:creator>Maggie Fox</dc:creator>
      <description>A raised red rash, bloodshot eyes and achy joints marked one man's bout with Zika.</description>
      <media:content url="http://media4.s-nbcnews.com/i/newscms/2016_19/1533061/160511-zika-dermatology-mn-1120_179b93f533ae806690185c53af0efcba.jpg" medium="image" height="1967" width="2500">
        <media:credit>Amit Garg, MD</media:credit>
        <media:text type="plain"></media:text>
        <media:description type="plain">A 44-year-old man developed a painful rash when he became infected with Zika virus in Puerto Rico.</media:description>
      </media:content>
      <media:content url="http://media3.s-nbcnews.com/i/newscms/2016_19/1532891/1160511-zika-dermatology-mn-1011_07a149f100f2a557001002cfe4ddd182.JPG" medium="image" height="149" width="275">
        <media:credit>Amit Garg, MD</media:credit>
        <media:text type="plain"></media:text>
        <media:description type="plain">A 44-year-old man developed a painful rash when he became infected with Zika virus in Puerto Rico.</media:description>
      </media:content>
      <media:content url="http://media2.s-nbcnews.com/i/newscms/2016_19/1532956/5160511-zika-dermatology-mn-1015_b9a3f90f531a2827ce0062c0a1626f4f.jpg" medium="image" height="2500" width="1915">
        <media:credit>Amit Garg, MD</media:credit>
        <media:text type="plain"></media:text>
        <media:description type="plain">A 44-year-old man developed a painful rash when he became infected with Zika virus in Puerto Rico.</media:description>
      </media:content>
    </item>
    <item>
      <guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.nbcnews.com/health/mental-health/club-drug-ketamine-rescues-suicidal-patients-study-n571571</guid>
      <title>'Club Drug' Ketamine Rescues Suicidal Patients: Study</title>
      <pubDate>Wed, 11 May 2016 14:06:27 GMT</pubDate>
      <link>http://www.nbcnews.com/health/mental-health/club-drug-ketamine-rescues-suicidal-patients-study-n571571</link>
      <dc:creator>Maggie Fox and Lauren Dunn and Felix Gussone, MD and Parminder Deo</dc:creator>
      <description>A 'club drug' used as an anesthetic can help clear up the distraught thinking of people on the brink of suicide, researchers reported Tuesday.</description>
      <media:content url="http://media2.s-nbcnews.com/i/newscms/2016_19/1532071/160510-liz-lehmann-and-daughters-yh-0618p_a60f66ac803127a93ca0576aef0d2d09.jpg" medium="image" height="1597" width="2500">
        <media:credit>Family photo</media:credit>
        <media:text type="plain">Image: Liz Lehmann</media:text>
        <media:description type="plain">Liz Lehmann and her two daughters Cassie, left, and Sam, right,  in Manhattan in May, 2016. Lehmann says ketamine pulled her out of her depression. </media:description>
      </media:content>
      <media:content url="http://media3.s-nbcnews.com/i/newscms/2016_19/1532086/160510-liz-lehmann-and-husband-yh-0630p_0a56b90813eea125038626f0059149ea.jpg" medium="image" height="1836" width="2500">
        <media:credit>Family photo</media:credit>
        <media:text type="plain">Image: Liz</media:text>
        <media:description type="plain">Liz Lehmann and husband Peter at the beach in Seaside Heights, New Jersey. Lehmann says ketamine pulled her out of a severe depression.</media:description>
      </media:content>
      <media:content url="http://media2.s-nbcnews.com/i/newscms/2016_19/1532071/160510-liz-lehmann-and-daughters-yh-0618p_a60f66ac803127a93ca0576aef0d2d09.jpg" medium="image" height="1597" width="2500">
        <media:credit>Family photo</media:credit>
        <media:text type="plain">Image: Liz Lehmann</media:text>
        <media:description type="plain">Liz Lehmann and her two daughters Cassie, left, and Sam, right,  in Manhattan in May, 2016.</media:description>
      </media:content>
    </item>
    <item>
      <guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.today.com/health/charla-nash-opens-about-recent-face-transplant-setback-living-independently-t91951</guid>
      <title>Charla Nash Opens Up About Face Transplant Setback</title>
      <pubDate>Wed, 11 May 2016 13:10:38 GMT</pubDate>
      <link>http://www.today.com/health/charla-nash-opens-about-recent-face-transplant-setback-living-independently-t91951</link>
      <dc:creator />
      <description>Charla Nash, the victim of a horrific attack by a friend's pet chimpanzee, had a setback last week when her body began to reject her face transplant.</description>
      <media:content url="http://media2.s-nbcnews.com/i/newscms/2016_19/1532746/charla_nash_68aac08d4445374f149863d2fee3b972.jpg" medium="image" height="394" width="700">
        <media:credit>TODAY</media:credit>
        <media:text type="plain">Image: Charla Nash.</media:text>
        <media:description type="plain">Charla Nash.</media:description>
      </media:content>
    </item>
    <item>
      <guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.nbcnews.com/storyline/zika-virus-outbreak/low-tech-trap-might-help-fight-zika-virus-outbreaks-cdc-n571501</guid>
      <title>Low-Tech Trap Might Help Fight Zika Virus Outbreaks</title>
      <pubDate>Wed, 11 May 2016 08:01:33 GMT</pubDate>
      <link>http://www.nbcnews.com/storyline/zika-virus-outbreak/low-tech-trap-might-help-fight-zika-virus-outbreaks-cdc-n571501</link>
      <dc:creator>Maggie Fox</dc:creator>
      <description>A low-tech mosquito trap might help control the mosquitoes that spread Zika virus, as well as other viruses such as dengue and chikungunya.</description>
      <media:content url="http://media2.s-nbcnews.com/i/newscms/2016_19/1531866/cdc_21081_ds5_bd004a969bd2bfa6623a9ef2b2e89696.jpeg" medium="image" height="419" width="600">
        <media:credit></media:credit>
        <media:text type="plain"></media:text>
        <media:description type="plain">This bucket trap was made by health officials in Puerto Rico. They hope it might help communities fight Zika virus.
Components include a black pail(a), a black pail lid(b), a 12.8cm entrance diameter(c), a black capture surface (CS) coated with adhesive(d), PAM(e), a 9.3 l capacity infusion reservoir(f), and a screen barrier between the CS and the infusion reservoir(g)</media:description>
      </media:content>
      <media:content url="http://media4.s-nbcnews.com/i/newscms/2016_19/1531881/cdc_21081_ds5_7ef34833f375a688bcffaccb9544ce2a.jpeg" medium="image" height="419" width="600">
        <media:credit>CDC</media:credit>
        <media:text type="plain"></media:text>
        <media:description type="plain">CDC and the Puerto Rico Department of Health designed this simple bucket trap to control Aedes aegypti mosquitoes</media:description>
      </media:content>
    </item>
    <item>
      <guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/michigan-man-nearly-killed-shooting-graduates-school-become-doctor-n571706</guid>
      <title>Detroit Shooting Survivor Finds Calling to Become Surgeon</title>
      <pubDate>Wed, 11 May 2016 00:13:00 GMT</pubDate>
      <link>http://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/michigan-man-nearly-killed-shooting-graduates-school-become-doctor-n571706</link>
      <dc:creator>Kevin Tibbles and Erik Ortiz</dc:creator>
      <description>The path that Kevin Morton Jr. is now on is a mission to help others — just like he was helped nine years ago as an ER trauma patient.</description>
      <media:content url="http://media4.s-nbcnews.com/i/newscms/2016_19/1532241/160510-doctor-kevin-morton-yh-0739p_2d92ee76ca77b1c5efc2c6b76e4a3fcf.jpg" medium="image" height="1518" width="2500">
        <media:credit>Nightly News</media:credit>
        <media:text type="plain">Image: Kevin Morton</media:text>
        <media:description type="plain">Kevin Morton.</media:description>
      </media:content>
      <media:content url="http://media4.s-nbcnews.com/i/newscms/2016_19/1532241/160510-doctor-kevin-morton-yh-0739p_2d92ee76ca77b1c5efc2c6b76e4a3fcf.jpg" medium="image" height="1518" width="2500">
        <media:credit>Nightly News</media:credit>
        <media:text type="plain">Image: Kevin Morton</media:text>
        <media:description type="plain">Kevin Morton.</media:description>
      </media:content>
      <media:content url="http://media3.s-nbcnews.com/i/newscms/2016_19/1532246/160510-kevin-morton-hospital-yh-0743p_fa7cd4e674149af5a94c3669953ca9c6.jpg" medium="image" height="2500" width="2033">
        <media:credit>via Nightly News</media:credit>
        <media:text type="plain">Image: Kevin Morton</media:text>
        <media:description type="plain">Kevin Morton in the hospital in 2007.</media:description>
      </media:content>
    </item>
    <item>
      <guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.today.com/health/driving-while-high-marijuana-causing-spike-fatal-accidents-t91746</guid>
      <title>Driving While High on Marijuana Causing Spike in Fatal Accidents</title>
      <pubDate>Tue, 10 May 2016 20:09:00 GMT</pubDate>
      <link>http://www.today.com/health/driving-while-high-marijuana-causing-spike-fatal-accidents-t91746</link>
      <dc:creator />
      <description>Nationally, more than half the drivers rushed to trauma centers after traffic accidents have drugs in their system...usually pot, officials say.</description>
      <media:content url="http://media4.s-nbcnews.com/i/newscms/2015_53/1306486/marijuana_3d477eda81c109b16d31bd110bd4aa38.jpg" medium="image" height="1722" width="2500">
        <media:credit>STEVE DIPAOLA</media:credit>
        <media:text type="plain">Image: A Cannabis plant is pictured at the "Weed the People" event as enthusiasts gather to celebrate the legalization of the recreational use of marijuana in Portland, Oregon</media:text>
        <media:description type="plain">A Cannabis plant. </media:description>
      </media:content>
    </item>
    <item>
      <guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.nbcnews.com/storyline/zika-virus-outbreak/urine-test-catches-zika-infection-better-cdc-says-n571371</guid>
      <title>Urine Test Catches Zika Infection Better, CDC Says</title>
      <pubDate>Tue, 10 May 2016 18:30:00 GMT</pubDate>
      <link>http://www.nbcnews.com/storyline/zika-virus-outbreak/urine-test-catches-zika-infection-better-cdc-says-n571371</link>
      <dc:creator />
      <description>A urine test catches Zika infection even a week after someone's recovered, the CDC says.</description>
      <media:content url="http://media3.s-nbcnews.com/i/newscms/2016_17/1430201/160223-zika-virus-mn-1450_0e301a4a6ece60c355ba4e5bd496b584.jpg" medium="image" height="1689" width="2500">
        <media:credit>INA FASSBENDER</media:credit>
        <media:text type="plain">Image: An employee examines tube with the label 'Zika virus' at Genekam Biotechnology AG in Duisburg</media:text>
        <media:description type="plain">An employee examines a tube with the label 'Zika virus' at Genekam Biotechnology AG in Duisburg, Germany, Feb. 2, 2016.</media:description>
      </media:content>
      <media:content url="http://media3.s-nbcnews.com/i/newscms/2016_17/1430201/160223-zika-virus-mn-1450_0e301a4a6ece60c355ba4e5bd496b584.jpg" medium="image" height="1689" width="2500">
        <media:credit>INA FASSBENDER</media:credit>
        <media:text type="plain">Image: An employee examines tube with the label 'Zika virus' at Genekam Biotechnology AG in Duisburg</media:text>
        <media:description type="plain">An employee examines a tube with the label 'Zika virus' at Genekam Biotechnology AG in Duisburg, Germany, Feb. 2, 2016.</media:description>
      </media:content>
    </item>

      <title>Could Diet Drinks Make Your Baby Fat?</title>

      <link>http://www.nbcnews.com/health/kids-health/could-diet-drinks-make-your-baby-fat-n570716</link>
      <dc:creator>Maggie Fox</dc:creator>
      <description>Babies whose moms drank diet drinks every day while pregnant are more likely to be overweight, researchers reported on Monday.</description>

      </media:content>
    </item>

    <item>
      <guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.nbcnews.com/health/health-news/malaria-vaccine-protects-half-who-try-it-n570656</guid>
      <title>Malaria Vaccine Protects Half Who Try It</title>
      <pubDate>Mon, 09 May 2016 19:16:00 GMT</pubDate>
      <link>http://www.nbcnews.com/health/health-news/malaria-vaccine-protects-half-who-try-it-n570656</link>
      <dc:creator>Maggie Fox</dc:creator>
      <description>An experimental malaria vaccine appears to protect half of the people who tried it for as long as a year, researchers said.</description>
      <media:content url="http://media4.s-nbcnews.com/i/newscms/2016_19/1529836/160509-sanaria-inc-malaria-workers-mdl_bd485afbe8b7eb5c50a7a4fd758063b2.jpg" medium="image" height="2188" width="2500">
        <media:credit>Sanaria, Inc.</media:credit>
        <media:text type="plain"></media:text>
        <media:description type="plain">Staff at Sanaria Inc. in Rockville, Maryland  take apart mosquitoes to remove the parasite that causes malaria. The company uses that parasites to make a vaccine against the disease, which kills nearly half a million people a year.</media:description>
      </media:content>
      <media:content url="http://media2.s-nbcnews.com/i/newscms/2016_19/1529841/160509-sanaria-inc-malaria_bd485afbe8b7eb5c50a7a4fd758063b2.jpg" medium="image" height="1556" width="2500">
        <media:credit>Sanaria, Inc.</media:credit>
        <media:text type="plain"></media:text>
        <media:description type="plain">Staff at Sanaria Inc. in Rockville, Maryland  take apart mosquitoes to remove the parasite that causes malaria. The company uses that parasites to make a vaccine against the disease, which kills nearly half a million people a year.</media:description>
      </media:content>
    </item>
    <item>
      <guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.nbcnews.com/health/health-news/facelift-bottle-second-skin-tightens-baggy-eyes-protects-dry-skin-n570521</guid>
      <title>Did These Researchers Invent a Facelift in a Bottle?</title>
      <pubDate>Mon, 09 May 2016 15:04:00 GMT</pubDate>
      <link>http://www.nbcnews.com/health/health-news/facelift-bottle-second-skin-tightens-baggy-eyes-protects-dry-skin-n570521</link>
      <dc:creator>Maggie Fox</dc:creator>
      <description>It sounds almost too good to be true — a two-step cream that tightens up baggy eyes and that can keep dry legs from flaking.</description>
      <media:content url="http://media4.s-nbcnews.com/i/newscms/2016_19/1529751/160509-second_skin-gonick-cream-mdl_b07089e163e3774cad54b204caf36f04.jpg" medium="image" height="2400" width="3600">
        <media:credit>Melanie Gonick/MIT</media:credit>
        <media:text type="plain"></media:text>
        <media:description type="plain">Researchers at MIT have developed a two-step cream that tightens and protects skin, providing a temporary face lift  and perhaps offering new ways to deliver drugs.</media:description>
      </media:content>
    </item>
    <item>

      <title>Obama Makes Mother's Day Plea to Address 'Diaper Gap'</title>
      <pubDate>Sun, 08 May 2016 17:57:00 GMT</pubDate>
      <link>http://www.nbcnews.com/politics/barack-obama/obama-makes-mother-s-day-plea-address-diaper-gap-n570141</link>
      <dc:creator>Christina Coleburn</dc:creator>
      <description>President Barack Obama commemorated Mother's Day with a Medium post explaining his plan to help families that have difficulty affording diapers.</description>

      </media:content>
